channel.title: Velociraptor Blog on Velociraptor - Digging deeper!
channel.description: Recent content in Velociraptor Blog on Velociraptor - Digging deeper!

item.title: WMI Event Consumers: what are you missing?
item.description: WMI Eventing is a fairly well known technique in DFIR however some tools may not provide the coverage you expect. This article covers WMI and specifically detection in less familiar custom namespaces.

item.title: Velociraptor 0.6.3 Release
item.description: Our latest Velociraptor release contains many new features and bug fixes. This post outlines some of the more interesting changes.

item.title: Searching for files
item.description: A common technique in DFIR is simply searching the filesystem for files. While this seems like a simple task, there are some surprising traps. This article covers some of the issues and possible solutions.

item.title: SFTP in AWS
item.description: Velociraptor can use sftp to securely transfer data to an AWS S3 bucket. However configuring this service securely is not trivial. This post walks the reader through the steps of setting up a secure sftp upload only bucket that can be used with Velociraptor.

item.title: EQL to VQL - Leverage EQL based detection rules in Velociraptor
item.description: There is a large body of existing work in detection queries and threat intelligence designed to work on top of a central data mining solution such as Elastic and its Event Query Language (EQL). By reusing existing detection resources within Velociraptor we are able to apply these in different contexts, enhancing their overall effectiveness.

item.title: Cobalt Strike payload discovery and data manipulation in VQL
item.description: This post walks through discovery of malicious files, then data manipulation and decode in VQL.

item.title: A Closer Look at the Winning Entry in the 2021 Velociraptor Contributor Competition
item.description: We take a look under the hood of the Grand Prize Winner

item.title: The 2021 Contributor Contest
item.description: The 2021 Velociraptor Contributor Competition has drawn to a close. Take a look at the winners and all the submissions.

item.title: Welcome to Velociraptor, Carlos
item.description: Carlos Canto joins Velociraptor as its new Community Manager. Read on to learn more.

item.title: Velociraptor 0.6.1 Release
item.description: Our latest Velociraptor release contains many new features and bug fixes. This post outlines some of the more interesting changes.

item.title: ETW Part 2: Process Parent Spoofing
item.description: This post takes another look at Event Tracing for Windows and how it can be used to detect a common attacker subversion technique.

item.title: Event Tracing for Windows Part 1
item.description: This post introduces ETW as an event source and examines how VQL can be used to harness the power of ETW.

item.title: Velociraptor vs Printnightmare
item.description: This post walks through a common use case for Velociraptor’s VQL: detecting exploitation of a new zero day (A newly announced vulnerability without a patch available). Once a zero day has been announced, time is of the essence! Defenders must scramble to determine possible remediations and detect exploitation on their network.

item.title: Carving $USN journal entries
item.description: The USN journal is a unique source of evidence because it can provide a timeline for when files were deleted, even if the file itself is no longer found on the system. While the USN journal is very useful, it is short lived. This post explains how to write a carver to recover deleted USN journal entries.

item.title: Verifying executables on Windows
item.description: How do we know if a windows executable is a legitimate program written by the purported developer and not malware? This post covers the basics of Authenticode signatures in windows and how to verify and query them using Velociraptor.

item.title: Scaling Velociraptor
item.description: Velociraptor is an endpoint visibility tool designed to query a large number of endpoints quickly and efficiently. This post introduces the new experimental multi-server architecture that is released in the 0.5.9 release.

item.title: The Next Phase of Velociraptor
item.description: Velociraptor is now part of Rapid7 - read about the transition and future plans.

item.title: Digging into process memory
item.description: Unlike traditional dead disk forensic tools, Velociraptor’s main advantage is that it is capable of directly looking at volatile system state, such as running processes, open files and currently connected sockets. This class of forensic artifacts are called Volatile Artifacts since they change rapidly as the system operates. Learn how Velociraptor collects volatile system state.

item.title: Digging for files with Velociraptor
item.description: The post covers a number of ways to find filesystem artifacts.

item.title: Migrating from OSQuery to Velociraptor
item.description: Many new Velociraptor users have existing OSQuery queries and installations and are migrating to Velociraptor for powerful and efficient endpoint visibility. This post summarizes some of the differences between Velociraptor and OSQuery.
